misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a distance calculator instead of a grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program computes the distance between two points and prints that distance, rather than reading a numeric grade and printing the corresponding letter grade as required. There is no logic to map grade ranges (A–F) to letter outputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to treat this file as solving a distance-between-points problem, possibly confusing it with another exercise or believing that this is an acceptable solution for the current question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program must read a numeric grade (0–100) from the user and use conditional logic to map it into the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, F), then print that letter grade in the required format.
symptoms: Class is named DistanceBetweenPoints and all main logic concerns coordinates and distances.
Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 rather than a single numeric grade.
Output message reports the distance between two points instead of a letter grade.
No if/else chain covers A–F ranges or prints any letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignments or reusing code from a different problem, leading to implementing the wrong algorithm for this question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and start a new program focused solely on reading a grade and printing its letter category. Ignore distance formulas and instead design an if/else-if chain that covers all grade ranges and prints the correct letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of main focuses on distance computation and none of the required grade-calculation behavior is present.

evidence.note: This code shows the entire program is dedicated to reading coordinates and computing a distance, with no grade-related input or letter-grade output as required.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded grade value instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: The program uses a hardcoded integer grade value (85) and only prints debug information about it, rather than reading a grade from the user and using it to determine and print a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to treat assigning int grade = 85 and checking it in an if-statement as sufficient for demonstrating grade handling, instead of actually reading the grade from the keyboard as the task requires.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user for a numeric grade and read it from the keyboard using Scanner (e.g., nextInt or nextDouble). That input value should then drive the conditional logic that maps to a letter grade.
symptoms: grade is initialized with a literal value rather than read from input.
No prompt asking the user to enter a grade.
The only use of grade is in debug prints and a single conditional; no letter grade is produced.
Scanner is used for coordinate input but never for reading a grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Possible confusion between test/debug code and final interactive behavior, or misunderstanding that the assignment explicitly requires reading the grade from the user rather than using a fixed value.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hardcoded grade with a prompt and Scanner call like `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();` and then base all grade-range checks on this input value.
related_concepts: Difference between literals and user input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is explicit Scanner usage for other values but not for grade, and grade is only ever assigned a constant and used for debug, suggesting a misunderstanding or incomplete implementation.

evidence.note: Here the grade is hardcoded as 85 and only used in debug output and a range check; there is no user prompt or input for the grade.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Assignment Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code intended for calculating the distance between two points, identified by the class name `DistanceBetweenPoints` and the logic for reading four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and calculating distance. This code does not address the Grade Calculator problem (Q3) requirements at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this submission fulfills the requirements for Q3, possibly due to submitting the wrong file or copying the wrong template.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and output a letter grade based on defined ranges.
symptoms: Code prompts for coordinates instead of grade
Calculates distance instead of assigning grades
Class name does not match assignment context
misconceptions.root_cause: Mismanagement of files or assignment instructions, resulting in submission of code for an entirely different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the correct file and problem solution are submitted for the assignment question.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, inputs, and primary calculation (distance formula) all confirm the code is for a different purpose.

evidence.note: The class name indicates this code solves the Distance Between Points problem, not the Grade Calculator.
Input is for coordinates (x1, y1), not a numeric grade.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
		System.out.println("Debug: Calculated distance = " + distance);
evidence.note: The core calculation is the distance formula, not grade logic.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Confusion between Logical AND (&&) and Bitwise AND (&)
misconceptions.description: In an auxiliary debug block, the student uses the single ampersand (`&`), which is the bitwise/non-short-circuit AND, for combining boolean logic in a conditional statement. Standard practice for flow control dictates using the logical short-circuit AND (`&&`).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that `&` and `&&` are interchangeable for conditional checks in an `if` statement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The logical short-circuit AND (`&&`) is generally preferred for `if` statements as it prevents evaluation of the second operand if the first is false, improving efficiency and preventing side effects. `&` always evaluates both operands.
symptoms: Inappropriate use of bitwise operator for flow control
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of clarity or distinction between short-circuit and non-short-circuit logical operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the difference between the short-circuit logical operator (`&&`) and the non-short-circuit operator (`&`) when used in boolean expressions. Always use `&&` for standard conditional checks.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The usage is explicit in the code, although it is contained within a debug block and does not affect the main program flow (of the distance calculator).

evidence.note: The single '&' is used for conditional checking instead of the preferred short-circuit '&&'.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Bitwise AND operator used for boolean logic
misconceptions.description: Student uses single & (bitwise AND) instead of && (logical AND) for boolean range checking in conditional statements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The single & operator can be used interchangeably with && for boolean logic in if statements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use && (logical AND) for boolean conditions. Single & is the bitwise AND operator and while it may produce correct results in some cases, it is semantically incorrect for boolean logic and lacks short-circuit evaluation.
symptoms: Line 28 uses 'grade >= 80 & grade < 90' instead of 'grade >= 80 && grade < 90'
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators (&, |, ^) and logical operators (&&, ||) in Java. The student may not understand the distinction between bitwise and logical operations.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use && for 'AND' logic in conditionals and || for 'OR' logic. Use &, |, ^ only when explicitly performing bitwise operations on integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student explicitly uses & in a boolean conditional context (line 28), which clearly demonstrates this operator confusion. However, this is a minor issue in an overall submission that has much larger problems.

evidence.note: Uses single & (bitwise AND) instead of && (logical AND) for boolean range checking.

misconceptions.name: Hard-coding grade instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: The program never asks the user for a numeric grade (0-100). Instead, it hard-codes `int grade = 85;` and uses that value in a debug-only conditional. The Scanner is only used for coordinate input, not for the grade the assignment requires.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that for this assignment it is acceptable to set `grade` directly in code (e.g., `int grade = 85;`) rather than reading the grade from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must prompt the user (e.g., `Enter grade:`) and read the numeric grade from the keyboard using a `Scanner` call such as `nextInt()` or `nextDouble()`, then base the letter-grade logic on that input.
symptoms: No prompt like `Enter grade:` appears anywhere in the program.
No `Scanner` call (e.g., `nextInt()` or `nextDouble()`) is used to read a grade.
The only grade-related value is `int grade = 85;`, which is a constant in the code.
The grade logic is only used for a debug message and not as part of a full grade calculator.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment requirements or reusing a different example program, leading the student to treat the grade as a test value instead of required user input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded `int grade = 85;` with a prompt and a `Scanner` call to read the grade from the user, e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();` and then use that variable in your letter-grade conditions.
related_concepts: Separating test values from required user input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only mention of a grade is a hard-coded `int grade = 85;` and there is no input prompt or scanner read for a grade anywhere in the file, while the problem statement explicitly requires reading a grade.

evidence.note: Grade is hard-coded as 85 and only used in a debug conditional; no Scanner call reads a grade from the keyboard.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Did not implement numeric-to-letter grade mapping
misconceptions.description: The program never maps a numeric grade to a letter grade A–F. Instead, it calculates the distance between two points and prints that distance, while the grade-related code only prints a debug message if the hard-coded grade is between 80 and 90.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that this program can focus on computing and printing the distance between two points, and that a small debug condition on a grade variable is sufficient instead of a full A–F letter grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program for this question must take a numeric grade (0–100) and use a set of mutually exclusive conditional branches (if/else if/else) to output exactly one letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges.
symptoms: No `if/else if/else` chain that covers the A, B, C, D, and F ranges.
No output of the form `Letter grade: X` for any letter.
The only condition on `grade` checks a single range (80–90) and prints a debug line rather than a letter.
Main program logic and prompts are about points and distance, not about grades.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or focused on a different exercise (distance between points) and never implemented the required grade-mapping algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance-calculation logic with an `if/else if/else` chain based on the grade variable: check `grade >= 90`, `grade >= 80`, `grade >= 70`, `grade >= 60`, and use an `else` for `F`, printing `Letter grade: A` (or B, C, D, F) accordingly.
related_concepts: Designing code to match problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to distance computation with only a small debug condition involving grade, and there is no letter-grade output at all, which is a complete mismatch with the problem specification.

evidence.note: Core logic prompts for coordinates and computes distance, not letter grades. No branch outputs `A`, `B`, `C`, `D`, or `F`.
The only grade-related logic is a single conditional with a debug message; it does not map the grade to a letter or cover all required ranges.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation (Task Misalignment)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different programming problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of implementing the required Grade Calculator (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a previous or unrelated assignment (Distance Between Points) in place of the required Q3 Grade Calculator assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must address the specific requirements of the assignment, which is to read a single numeric grade and output a letter grade.
symptoms: The code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer/double grade input (0-100).
The program calculates distance using the distance formula instead of using conditional logic to assign a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major error in submission process or misunderstanding of which code file corresponds to the required assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please locate and submit the correct Java file containing the code for the Grade Calculator problem (Q3).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted file uses I/O and calculation steps entirely irrelevant to the Grade Calculator problem statement and perfectly matches a different, common programming exercise (Distance Formula).

evidence.note: The entire primary logic addresses distance calculation, not grade calculation.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Confusion between short-circuit (&&) and bitwise (&) AND operators
misconceptions.description: The student uses the single bitwise AND operator (`&`) for conditional checks within an `if` statement, where the logical short-circuit AND operator (`&&`) is conventionally required in Java for boolean expressions.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the single ampersand symbol (&) is the correct logical AND operator for combining boolean conditions in an `if` statement, similar to how it might be used in other languages or contexts.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, `&&` is the logical AND operator (short-circuiting), which is standard for combining boolean conditions. The single `&` is the bitwise AND operator, which works on boolean operands but evaluates both sides, potentially leading to performance waste or unexpected behavior if side effects were present, although in this minimal case, it evaluates correctly.
symptoms: Use of single '&' within a conditional expression.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion regarding Java's logical operators vs. bitwise operators, or transferring habits from C/C++ often used in CS education where `&` sometimes appears in conditional logic (though incorrectly, or specifically for bitwise checks only).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Java uses `&&` for the logical AND operation, which is generally preferred over `&` in `if` conditions because of short-circuiting.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The usage pattern `if (boolean_expression & boolean_expression)` is a classic symptom of this confusion (line 30). This chunk of code is a debug example and not the main solution, hence categorized as minor impact on the overall (misplaced) code structure.

evidence.note: The bitwise AND operator '&' is used instead of the logical AND operator '&&' to combine conditions.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Confusion between Bitwise AND (&) and Logical AND (&&) operators
misconceptions.description: The student used the single bitwise AND operator (&) instead of the logical AND operator (&&) when checking a compound boolean condition. While this code may compile and produce correct results in some cases due to type coercion, it shows a misunderstanding of the proper operator to use for boolean logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the bitwise AND operator (&) is equivalent to the logical AND operator (&&) for evaluating compound boolean conditions.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The && operator is the logical AND operator that should be used for boolean conditions and expressions. It performs short-circuit evaluation (if the left side is false, it doesn't evaluate the right side). The & operator is a bitwise AND operator used for integer bit manipulation, not boolean logic.
symptoms: Use of & instead of && in a conditional statement
Semantic incorrectness even if code happens to run
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about operator types and their purposes in Java. The student may not understand the distinction between bitwise operations and logical operations, or may have confused similar-looking operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the single & with && in the condition: `if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)` instead of `if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90)`. Review the Java operators and when to use each one.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the student explicitly wrote 'single &' in a boolean condition (line 27), which is clear evidence of using the wrong operator. The pattern is unambiguous.

evidence.note: The condition uses single & (bitwise AND) instead of && (logical AND). The comment even acknowledges 'using single &', suggesting the student was aware of the difference but chose the wrong operator anyway.
